review.title: Identifying Consistent Statements about Numerical Data with Dispersion-Corrected Subgroup Discovery
review.abstract: Existing algorithms for subgroup discovery with numerical targets do not optimize the error or target variable dispersion of the groups they find. This often leads to unreliable or inconsistent statements about the data, rendering practical applications, especially in scientific domains, futile. Therefore, we here extend the optimistic estimator framework for optimal subgroup discovery to a new class of objective functions: we show how tight estimators can be computed efficiently for all functions that are determined by subgroup size (non-decreasing dependence), the subgroup median value, and a dispersion measure around the median (non-increasing dependence). In the important special case when dispersion is measured using the average absolute deviation from the median, this novel approach yields a linear time algorithm. Empirical evaluation on a wide range of datasets shows that, when used within branch-and-bound search, this approach is highly efficient and indeed discovers subgroups with much smaller errors.
histories: significance of empirical results tested; additional illustrations; table of used notations

metadata.title: Identifying Consistent Statements about Numerical Data with Dispersion-Corrected Subgroup Discovery

sections.heading: 2. Subgroup Discovery
sections.text: Before developing the novel approach of rigorous calculation of optimistic estimators, we will recall in this section the necessary foundations for optimal discovery of subgroups with numerical target attributes. We will focus on concepts that are essential from the point of view of optimization (see, for example, Duivesteijn and Knobbe 2011 and references to them for statistical considerations).As a fictitious convention, we will use the symbol [m] for a positive integer m to denote the integer {1,..., m}.We will also write (x) + to denote max {x, 0} for a real expression of x. A summary of the most important notations used in this essay can be found in Appendix C.

sections.heading: 2.1. Description languages, objective functions, and closed selectors
sections.text: Let P denote our given global population of entities for which we each know the value of a real target variable Q = Q (Q → R) and additional descriptive information known in any abstract description language L from subgroup selectors σ: P → {true, false} Each of these selectors describes a subpopulation statement that has a useful (or interesting) distribution of target values in its extent.

sections.heading: 3. Efficiently Computable Tight Optimistic Estimators
sections.text: We will develop an efficient algorithm for the tight optimistic estimator in three steps: First, we will test and formulate a general algorithm for the classic case of non-dispersion conscious objective functions. Then we will apply the basic idea of this algorithm to the case of dispersion-corrected targets based on the median, and finally we will consider a subclass of these functions where the approach can be calculated in linear time. In this section we will identify a given subpopulation Q'P with the multiset of its target values {y1,...,..., ym} and assume that the target values are indexed in ascending order, i.e. yi ≤ yj for i ≤ j. In addition, it is helpful to define the following partial order defined on finite multisets. Let us leave Y = {y1,..., ym} and Z = {z1,.., zm ′} two multisets so that their elements are indexed in ascending order.

sections.heading: 3.1. The standard case: monotone functions of a central tendency measure
sections.text: The previous general approach to calculating the narrow optimistic estimate for the subgroup discovery with a metric target variable is described by Q = Q (2016), where it is incrementally referred to as an estimate. Here, we review this approach and give a consistent and generalized version of the results of this paper. To this end, we define the general notion of a measure of the central tendency as the following. It can be verified that this definition applies to the standard measures of the central tendency, i.e., the arithmetic and geometric averages, as well as the median2 med. (Q) = ydm / 2e, and to weighted variants thereof (note) that it does not apply to the mode.

sections.heading: 3.2. Dispersion-corrected objective functions based on the median
sections.text: We will extend the previous formula for calculating the narrow optimistic estimator to objective functions that depend not only on the size of the subpopulation and its central tendency, but also on the target dispersion in the subgroup. Specifically, we will focus on the median as a measure of the central tendency and consider functions that decrease both monotonously in the described subpopulation size and monotonously in any dispersion size. To describe exactly this function class, we must formalize the term dispersion size around the median. For our purpose, the following definition suffices. Let us look at the multiplication of absolute differences to the median of a multiset Y class, i.e. Y med.

sections.heading: 3.3. Reaching linear time—objectives based on dispersion-corrected coverage
sections.text: Equipped with the general concept of the median sequence, we can now address the specific case of dispersion-corrected objective functions, where the trade-off between the subpopulation size and the target dispersion is captured by a linear function of the size and the sum of absolute differences from the median. Specifically, let us define the dispersion-corrected coverage (i.e., the absolute median deviation is) where smd (Q) = the sum of absolute deviations from the median. We then consider objective functions based on the dispersion-corrected coverage of formf (Q) = g (dcc (Q), med (Q)), where g does not decrease.

sections.heading: 4. Dispersion-corrected Subgroup Discovery in Practice
sections.text: The overall result of Sec. 3 is an efficient algorithm for dispersion correction. To evaluate this efficiency requirement as well as the value of the dispersion correction, let us consider normalization as our goal.

sections.heading: 4.1. Selection Bias of Dispersion-Correction and its Statistical Merit
sections.text: To investigate the divergence of f1, we also consider the non-divergence-corrected variant f0 (Q) = Q (Q) = cov (Q) mds + (Q), where we simply replace the divergence-corrected reporting with normal reporting. This function is a monotonous Level 1 function, so its strict optimistic estimator f (Q) mds + (Q) can be calculated in linear time using the top sequence approach. Figure 4 shows the characteristics of the optimal subgroups discovered in relation to both of these objective functions (see also Tab. 1 for exact values), where the language of closed conjunctions Ccnj was used as the description language for all datasets. The first observation is that - as forced by design - the mean absolute deviation from the median variant is lower for all datasets (except in a case where both functions result in the same subgroup).

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: During the preceding sections, we developed and evaluated an effective algorithm for simultaneously optimizing size, central tendency, and dispersion in subgroup discovery with a numerical target. However, this algorithm is based on two central results: 1) the strict optimistic estimator for each objective function based on any dispersion measurement around the median cannot be calculated as the maximum of the function on a linear sequence of sentences - the median sequence (Prop. 2); and 2) for objective functions based on the concept of dispersion-corrected reporting. Absolute deviation from the median, individual sequence of the median sequence can be generated in incremental constant time (Thm. 3).Among the possible applications of the proposed approach, it is perhaps most important to replace the standard coverage in classical objective functions with dispersion-corrected reporting, d..

metadata.abstractText: Existing algorithms for subgroup discovery with numerical targets do not optimize the error or target variable dispersion of the groups they find. This often leads to unreliable or inconsistent statements about the data, rendering practical applications, especially in scientific domains, futile. Therefore, we here extend the optimistic estimator framework for optimal subgroup discovery to a new class of objective functions: we show how tight estimators can be computed efficiently for all functions that are determined by subgroup size (non-decreasing dependence), the subgroup median value, and a dispersion measure around the median (nonincreasing dependence). In the important special case when dispersion is measured using the mean absolute deviation from the median, this novel approach yields a linear time algorithm. Empirical evaluation on a wide range of datasets shows that, when used within branch-and-bound search, this approach is highly efficient and indeed discovers subgroups with much smaller errors.
